p: Since the dissemination of Kochâ€™s Postulates, we have developed a more nuanced understanding of the roles of host and environmental factors that, together with the characteristics of the microbial agents, combine to either produce disease or not. Attempts to develop an alternative set of criteria upon which to base the attribution of a case to a microbial agent have not produced a universally accepted substitute. As we come to understand what a small proportion of the human microbial flora can be cultivated and the effects of the microbiome on health, the need for better criteria for ascribing a causal role in disease to one or more microorganisms has increased.
